TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi serializable sealed DigitShapes extends System.Enum

Docs.summary: Specifies the culture-specific display of digits.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A <xref:System.Globalization.DigitShapes> value specifies that no digit shape is substituted for the Unicode input, a digit shape is substituted based on context, or a native national digit shape is substituted for the input.
The Arabic, Indic, and Thai languages have classical shapes for numbers that are different from the digits 0 through 9 (Unicode U+0030 through U+0039), which are most often used on computers. The application uses the <xref:System.Globalization.DigitShapes> enumeration with the <xref:System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo.DigitSubstitution%2A> property to specify how to display digits U+0030 through U+0039 in the absence of other formatting information.
The <xref:System.Globalization.DigitShapes> enumeration is primarily used by applications intended for cultures that use bidirectional scripts. For example, the reading order of Arabic and Indic scripts is bidirectional.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Globalization.DigitShapes Context = int32(0)

Docs.summary: The digit shape depends on the previous text in the same output. European digits follow Latin scripts; Arabic-Indic digits follow Arabic text; and Thai digits follow Thai text.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Globalization.DigitShapes NativeNational = int32(2)

Docs.summary: The digit shape is the native equivalent of the digits from 0 through 9. ASCII digits from 0 through 9 are replaced by equivalent native national digits.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Globalization.DigitShapes None = int32(1)

Docs.summary: The digit shape is not changed. Full Unicode compatibility is maintained.
